questions.text: A pregnant female who is a known case of bronchial asthma presented to hospital with blood pressure of 160/100 mm Hg. Which of the following is the preferred drug for this patient? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nifedipine

 

Considering the patient's condition of bronchial asthma, beta-blockers like labetalol and propranolol may not be the best choices due to the risk of exacerbating asthma. Nicardipine, a calcium channel blocker, is a safer alternative in this scenario. It effectively lowers blood pressure and is safe to use in pregnancy, without the risk of bronchoconstriction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral Labetalol: Labetalol is a beta-blocker with alpha-blocking activity. It is commonly used for hypertension in pregnancy. However, being a beta-blocker, it can potentially exacerbate bronchial asthma by causing bronchoconstriction.

 

Option B. Intravenous Labetalol: This would be used for more immediate control of severely elevated blood pressure, like in a hypertensive crisis. The same concerns regarding bronchial asthma apply as with oral labetalol.

 

Option D. Propranolol: This is a non-selective beta-blocker and is generally contraindicated in asthma because it can cause bronchoconstriction. It is also not the first choice for managing hypertension in pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nifedipine, a calcium channel blocker is effective in lowering blood pressure and is generally considered safe in pregnancy. It does not have the bronchoconstrictive effects associated with beta-blockers.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female consumed a white colored rodenticide powder and presents with a potassium level of 2.5 mEq/L. She has irregular pulse and muscle paralysis. ECG shows multiple ventricular ectopic beats. What is the suspected poison? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Barium Carbonate

 

Barium carbonate poisoning is characterized by severe hypokalemia (low potassium levels), which leads to symptoms such as muscle paralysis and irregular pulse. The ECG changes, such as multiple ventricular ectopic beats, are also indicative of hypokalemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aluminum Phosphide: This poison releases phosphine gas in the stomach, which inhibits cytochrome C oxidase and causes oxidative stress, leading to cytotoxic effects. The main symptom is profound hypotension, not hypokalemia.

 

Option B. Zinc Phosphide: Similar to aluminum phosphide, zinc phosphide also releases phosphine gas and causes oxidative stress and cytochrome C oxidase inhibition, leading to cytotoxic effects and profound hypotension, not hypokalemia.

 

Option D. Warfarin: Warfarin is an anticoagulant that causes bleeding and bruising with an elevated PT/INR, but it does not cause hypokalemia or the associated symptoms described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypokalemia with symptoms such as muscle paralysis, irregular pulse, and ECG changes like ventricular ectopic beats strongly suggest poisoning with barium carbonate.

choices.text: Anatomical closure of foramen ovale is by 3 to 5 days
Anatomical closure of ductus venosus is by 3 to 7 days
Anatomical closure of ductus arteriosus is by 2 to 3 weeks

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding fetal circulation is incorrect ? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Anatomical closure of foramen ovale is by 3 to 5 days

 

The foramen ovale is an opening in the interatrial septum that allows blood to flow directly from the right atrium to the left atrium, bypassing the lungs. After birth, as the baby begins to breathe and the lungs expand, the pressure in the left atrium increases relative to the right atrium, causing the flap-like valve of the foramen ovale to close.

 

Functional closure, where the valve is pressed shut due to the pressure difference between the atria, usually occurs immediately after birth. Anatomical closure, where the tissue actually grows together and seals the foramen, typically occurs within the first year of life, but not as quickly as 3 to 5 days. Hence, this statement is false.

 

Usually it takes anywhere between 1 to 12 months for the anatomical closure of foramen ovale

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anatomical closure of ductus venosus is by 3 to 7 days:

 

  • The ductus venosus connects the umbilical vein to the inferior vena cava, allowing oxygenated blood from the placenta to bypass the liver and flow directly to the heart.
  • After birth, the ductus venosus constricts and eventually closes, typically within a few days to a week. It becomes a fibrous cord known as the ligamentum venosum.

 

Option C. Right umbilical vein is absent:

 

  • In fetal circulation, there are two umbilical arteries and one umbilical vein. The umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus. It's noteworthy that only the left umbilical vein persists, while the right one regresses early in development. Hence, this statement is accurate.

 

Option D. Anatomical closure of ductus arteriosus is by 2 to 3 weeks:

 

  • The ductus arteriosus is a vessel that connects the pulmonary artery to the descending aorta. It allows blood to bypass the fetal lungs, which are not yet functional for breathing.
  • After birth, increased oxygen concentration and decreased levels of certain prostaglandins cause the ductus arteriosus to constrict. Functional closure usually happens within the first couple of days after birth, and it undergoes anatomical closure (becoming the ligamentum arteriosum) typically within the first few weeks to months of life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anatomical closure of the foramen ovale takes 1 month to a year.

questions.text: After a severe penetrating head trauma, what is the risk of subsequent epilepsy? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 45%

 

Explanation:

 

According to Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, the risk of developing subsequent epilepsy after severe penetrating head trauma is approximately 45%. This statistic highlights the significant risk associated with severe brain injuries, particularly those involving penetration, which can lead to long-term neurological complications such as epilepsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The risk of developing epilepsy after severe penetrating head trauma is approximately 45%.

questions.text: Identify the investigation shown. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PET

 

The image provided shows a comparison between three types of imaging modalities: PET, CT, and PET-CT. PET (Positron Emission Tomography) is a nuclear medicine functional imaging technique used to observe metabolic processes in the body. In this case, the PET scan highlights areas of the body where the radioactive glucose analog 18F-FDG has been absorbed, typically areas with high glucose metabolism such as tumors.

 

The combined PET-CT image integrates the metabolic information from the PET scan with the anatomical detail provided by the CT scan, which allows for precise localization of the metabolic activity within the body's structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. USG: Ultrasound (USG) uses sound waves to create images of the inside of the body. It does not produce the type of image shown in this question.

 

Option B. MRI: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) uses strong magnetic fields and radio waves to produce detailed images of the body's internal structures. The images from MRI are different from those of PET scans, which focus on metabolic activity.

 

Option D. X-ray: X-rays provide images based on the absorption of X-ray photons by different tissues, primarily used to visualize bone structures. The image shown is not an X-ray, as it does not display the typical bone-focused detail of X-ray imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The investigation shown in the image is a PET scan (and PET-CT), which highlights areas of high metabolic activity, commonly used for detecting cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following method is shown in the surgical procedure to close the abdominal wound with the help of a mesh? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Onlay

 

The image shows a mesh placed over the abdominal muscles to close a wound, which is indicative of the onlay method. In the onlay technique, the mesh is placed on top of the rectus sheath and anterior abdominal wall muscles. This is typically used in open ventral hernia repairs where the mesh is laid directly on top of the closed fascial layer. This method is chosen for its simplicity and effectiveness in reinforcing the abdominal wall from the outside.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sublay: In this method, the mesh is placed beneath the rectus muscles but above the peritoneum. It is also known as the retromuscular or sublay position. This is not the method shown in the image.

 

Option C. Inlay: This method involves placing the mesh between the edges of the defect without overlapping. This is generally used when the defect cannot be closed primarily. The image does not show this technique.

 

Option D. Intraperitoneal (Underlay): In this method, the mesh is placed inside the peritoneal cavity in direct contact with the abdominal organs. The image does not show this; instead, it shows the mesh being placed on top of the abdominal wall.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The onlay method involves placing the mesh on top of the abdominal muscles and rectus sheath, commonly used in open ventral hernia repairs.

questions.text: What does phase III represent in the below image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Alveolar plateau

 

The image represents a capnography waveform, which displays the concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2) in exhaled air. Phase III of the capnography waveform, also known as the alveolar plateau, represents the period during exhalation where CO2 levels plateau as alveolar gas is exhaled. This phase reflects the CO2 concentration from the alveoli, which is relatively stable until the end of expiration. The end of phase III corresponds to the end-tidal CO2 (EtCO2), a key measurement in monitoring ventilation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phase III of the capnography waveform, also known as the alveolar plateau, represents the exhalation of alveolar gas and is used to determine the end-tidal CO2 level.

questions.text: In a case of RTA (Road Traffic Accident), a person has died. Who can order an autopsy? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Police Officer


In cases of deaths such as those resulting from road traffic accidents, the decision to conduct an autopsy is made by the Investigating Officer (IO), typically a Police Officer. The Police Officer is responsible for the inquest, which involves examining the circumstances of the death and deciding whether an autopsy is necessary to determine the cause of death. While the actual conduction of the autopsy is performed by a forensic doctor, the authorization comes from the Police Officer handling the case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Public Prosecutor: The Public Prosecutor is involved in legal proceedings but does not have the authority to order an autopsy. Their role begins after the investigation and autopsy have been conducted and evidence is gathered.

 

Option B. Defendant Lawyer: The Defendant Lawyer represents the accused in legal proceedings and has no authority to order an autopsy. Their role is strictly legal defense, not investigative.

 

Option D. Forensic Medicine Doctor: The Forensic Medicine Doctor conducts the autopsy but does not have the authority to order one. They act upon the request of the Investigating Officer who is in charge of the case.

 

Educational Objective:


The Police Officer, specifically the Investigating Officer, has the authority to order an autopsy in cases of unexplained or suspicious deaths, such as those resulting from a road traffic accident.

questions.text: Fibers from the structure marked in blue, terminate at which of the following? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Red nucleus

 

The superior cerebellar peduncle is the peduncle that is highlighted in the picture. Deep cerebellar nuclei that extend to the brainstem, red nucleus, and thalamus are connected by fibres to the superior cerebellar peduncle. The fibres of the ventral spinocerebellar tract are also present.

 

 

 

All of the efferent fibres from the dentate, emboliform, and globose nuclei Majority of efferents from the fastigial nucleus pass via inferior cerebellar peduncle though few may pass via superior peduncle. The caudal mesencephalon is where its fibres decussate, and they are intended to synapse in the thalamus and opposite red nucleus. Only afferent fibres from the contralateral pontine nuclei are present in the middle cerebellar peduncle. Afferent and efferent fibres that travel to the vestibular nuclei are both present in the inferior cerebellar peduncle.

 

The image below summarizes the various tracts in the cerebellar unit.

 

 

  • It has two surfaces - superior and inferior separated by a horizontal fissure. It is connected to the other parts of the central nervous system via three peduncles
    • Superior cerebellar peduncle -connecting to the midbrain
    • Middle cerebellar peduncle - connecting to the pons
    • Inferior cerebellar peduncle - connecting to the medulla oblongata

 

The superior cerebellar peduncle, also known as the brachium conjunctivum, is a major white matter tract connecting the cerebellum to the midbrain. Its fibers originate in the cerebellum, ascend, and decussate (cross over) at the level of the midbrain to end primarily in the contralateral red nucleus and the thalamus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fastigial nucleus: The fastigial nucleus is one of the four deep cerebellar nuclei (others being the globose, emboliform, and dentate nuclei). While the fastigial nucleus does send fibers out of the cerebellum, it primarily connects through the inferior cerebellar peduncle to the vestibular nuclei and the reticular formation, not the superior cerebellar peduncle.

 

Option B. Inferior olivary nucleus: The inferior olivary nucleus is located in the medulla oblongata and is involved in motor learning and coordination. It primarily sends fibers to the cerebellum through the inferior cerebellar peduncle, and it receives cerebellar feedback, but not directly from the superior cerebellar peduncle.

 

Option D. Subthalamus: The subthalamus is part of the diencephalon and is closely related to the basal ganglia circuitry, particularly in the indirect pathway. While the subthalamus does receive some cerebellar input, the primary connection from the superior cerebellar peduncle is to the red nucleus and not directly to the subthalamus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The red nucleus is located in the midbrain and plays a role in motor coordination. Fibers from the cerebellum via the superior cerebellar peduncle decussate and terminate primarily in the contralateral red nucleus. From the red nucleus, some of these fibers continue on to the thalamus. Thus, the red nucleus is a major target of the superior cerebellar peduncle fibers.

questions.text: Local anesthesia used in cataract surgery is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lignocaine 2%

 

Lignocaine 2% (also known as lidocaine) is the most commonly used local anesthetic for cataract surgery. It provides effective and rapid onset of anesthesia, making it ideal for this type of procedure. Lignocaine is typically used for infiltration anesthesia, which involves injecting the anesthetic around the eye to block nerve impulses.

 

Types of Local Anesthesia:

 

  • Infiltrating Type: This involves injecting the anesthetic directly into the tissue to numb a specific area.
  • Topical: Applied directly to the surface of the skin or mucous membranes. Best drug is proparacain

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bupivacaine 0.5%:  While bupivacaine can be used in ophthalmic surgery, it's generally reserved for cases where longer-lasting anesthesia is required. It's not the first choice for routine cataract surgery.

 

Option C. Prilocaine 0.5%:  Prilocaine is sometimes used in dental procedures but is not commonly used in ophthalmic surgery.

 

Option D. Ropivacaine 0.05%:  Ropivacaine is used in various surgical procedures but is not typically the first choice for cataract surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lignocaine 2% is the standard local anesthetic used in cataract surgery due to its rapid onset and appropriate duration of action. However, it's important to note that topical anesthesia using proparacaine 0.5% is becoming increasingly common in modern cataract surgery techniques.

questions.text: Which injury is not a part of ‘terrible triad of elbow’? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fracture of olecranon

 

TERRIBLE TRIAD OF ELBOW

 

  • A notoriously unstable injury is the elbow dislocation with associated fractures of the radial head and coronoid process of the ulna is termed the terrible triad of the elbow.
  • Elbow dislocation is often associated with posterolateral dislocation or LCL injury.
  • Mechanism of injury is fall on supinated forearm and extended arm that results in a combination of valgus, axial, and posterolateral rotatory forces.
  • This produces posterolateral dislocation.
  • Structures of elbow fail from lateral to medial:  
    • LCL
    • Anterior capsule
    • Possible MCL disruption
  • Patients complain of pain, clicking and locking with elbow in extension.
  • Physical examination shows possible varus / valgus instability patterns.
  • Radiographs help evaluate the concentricity of humeroulnar and radiocapitellar joints; specifically, lateral films can assist in diagnosing coronoid fractures.

 

 

  • CT scan is routinely obtained to identify fracture patterns, comminution, and displacement, which may not be evident on plain radiographs. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fracture of olecranon is not a part of the terrible triad injury of the elbow.
  • In the terrible triad injury, the radial head and coronoid process are fractured, along with dislocation of the elbow joint.

choices.text: Mass as shown should be removed
Mass should be reduced by a surgical procedure and mesh repair should be done
Mass should be reduced and anatomical repair by suturing the abdominal wall defect should be done
Mass should be reduced, mesh repair done and the redundant skin should be excised

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the patient who presented with the following as shown in the image. Earlier the abdominal mass was reducible, but now it has become irreducible? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mass should be reduced, mesh repair done and the redundant skin should be excised

 

The patient presents with an irreducible umbilical or para-umbilical hernia, as indicated by the previously reducible abdominal mass that has now become irreducible. This condition necessitates surgical intervention. The correct management involves reducing the hernia, repairing the defect with a mesh to prevent recurrence, and excising the redundant skin, especially if it appears stretched, unhealthy, or ulcerated. This comprehensive approach ensures both the structural repair and the removal of any compromised skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mass as shown should be removed: Simply removing the mass without addressing the hernia repair and the redundant skin does not resolve the underlying issue and may lead to recurrence or complications.

 

Option B. Mass should be reduced by a surgical procedure and mesh repair should be done: While this option addresses the hernia reduction and repair, it does not consider the removal of unhealthy or redundant skin, which is necessary in cases of long-standing hernias with poor skin quality.

 

Option C. Mass should be reduced and anatomical repair by suturing the abdominal wall defect should be done: Anatomical repair alone, without the use of mesh, is less effective for ventral hernias and has a higher risk of recurrence. Mesh repair is the standard approach.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For an irreducible umbilical or para-umbilical hernia, the recommended treatment includes hernia reduction, mesh repair, and excision of redundant or unhealthy skin to ensure a durable and effective repair.

questions.text: What is the antihypertensive of choice in a 28-week preeclamptic woman with asthma? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nifedipine

 

Explanation:

 

In managing preeclampsia, labetalol is often the first-line antihypertensive due to its efficacy and safety profile in pregnancy. However, labetalol is both an alpha and beta-blocker, and its use can exacerbate asthma by causing bronchoconstriction. Therefore, it is contraindicated in asthmatic patients.

 

Nifedipine: This is a calcium channel blocker that is safe and effective in pregnancy. It does not have the bronchoconstrictive effects of labetalol, making it the antihypertensive of choice for a preeclamptic woman with asthma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral labetalol and Option B. IV labetalol: Both forms are contraindicated in patients with asthma due to the risk of bronchoconstriction.

 

Option D. Telmisartan: This angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) is contraindicated in pregnancy because it can cause fetal renal hypoperfusion and oligohydramnios, among other teratogenic effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nifedipine is the antihypertensive of choice in a preeclamptic woman with asthma due to its safety profile and lack of broncho constrictive effects.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are independently false statements.
The assertion is independently a true statement, but the reason is independently a false statement.
Both assertion and reason are independently true statements, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion.
Both assertion and reason are independently true statements, and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion.

questions.text:
Choose the most appropriate answer: (INICET NOV 2022)

 

Assertion: In phenylketonuria, the urine has a mousy odor.

 

Reason: The serum levels of tyrosine, dopamine, and norepinephrine are decreased in phenylketonuria.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both assertion and reason are independently true statements, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion.

 

  • Assertion: The statement that "In phenylketonuria, the urine has a mousy odor" is true. The mousy or musty odor of the urine in phenylketonuria (PKU) is due to the accumulation of phenylacetate, one of the metabolites of phenylalanine.
  • Reason: The statement that "The serum levels of tyrosine, dopamine, and norepinephrine are decreased in phenylketonuria" is also true. Phenylketonuria is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase, which converts phenylalanine to tyrosine. Consequently, low levels of tyrosine lead to reduced synthesis of catecholamines such as dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine.

 

However, the reason provided is not the correct explanation for the assertion. The mousy odor in PKU is directly related to the accumulation of phenylacetate, not to the decreased levels of tyrosine or catecholamines.

 

Detailed Mechanism:

 

  • Phenylketonuria (PKU): PKU is an inborn error of metabolism caused by a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase or, less commonly, a defect in enzymes responsible for producing tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4). This defect results in impaired conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine, leading to the accumulation of phenylalanine and its metabolites, such as phenylpyruvate and phenylacetate, which are excreted in the urine.
  • Tyrosine and Catecholamine Synthesis: Tyrosine is a precursor for the synthesis of catecholamines, including dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine. In PKU, the deficiency of tyrosine leads to reduced synthesis of these neurotransmitters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In phenylketonuria, the mousy odor of urine is due to the accumulation of phenylacetate, while decreased levels of tyrosine and catecholamines are a result of the impaired conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine. However, the two phenomena are not causally related.

choices.text: Mannitol salt agar
Xylose lysine deoxycholate agar
Sorbitol MacConkey agar

questions.text: Which of the following culture media is used to differentiate other E. coli species from E. coli O157: H7? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sorbitol MacConkey agar

 

E.coli O157: H7 can be differentiated from other E.coli species using sorbitol MacConkey agar.

 

There are more than 150 serotypes of Shiga toxin-producing E.Coli (STEC). Of these, 0157:7 is the most common type. Unlike most other E.Coli serotypes, the STEC 0157:H7 does not use sorbitol and produces clear colonies on the Sorbitol MacConkey agar.

 

O157: H7 strains also are negative for -glucuronidase using the substrate 4-methylumbelliferyl-B-glucuronide test. More than 90 per cent of other E. coli tests positive with this substrate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mannitol salt agar: This medium is primarily used for the isolation of Staphylococcus species because it contains high concentrations of salt, inhibiting most other bacteria.

 

Option B. Xylose lysine deoxycholate agar: Used for the isolation of Salmonella and Shigella species, which are also important enteric pathogens.

 

Option D. CLED (Cystine Lactose Electrolyte Deficient) medium: Designed for urinary tract infections to inhibit the swarming of Proteus species and allow the differentiation of other urinary pathogens based on lactose fermentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sorbitol MacConkey agar is critical for distinguishing E. coli O157 from other E. coli strains due to its unique inability to ferment sorbitol, helping guide appropriate public health responses and treatment options during outbreaks of foodborne illness.

questions.text:
A couple already has 3 children and has been trying for another one for the last 1 year. However, the husband is diagnosed with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Which of the following is/are true? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Low FSH, low LH
  2. High FSH, low LH
  3. Oligospermia
  4. Low prolactin
  5. Low testosterone
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3 and 5

 

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is a condition where there is decreased production of gonadotropins (FSH and LH) by the pituitary gland, leading to decreased stimulation of the testes and consequent reduced production of sex hormones such as testosterone. This results in:

 

1. Low FSH, low LH: In hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, both follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH) are low due to inadequate stimulation from the pituitary gland.

 

3. Oligospermia: Reduced levels of FSH and LH lead to decreased stimulation of the testes, which can result in reduced sperm production and oligospermia (low sperm count).

 

5. Low testosterone: Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism leads to reduced levels of testosterone because the testes are not adequately stimulated by FSH and LH.

 

The following are not true for hypogonadotropic hypogonadism:

 

2. High FSH, low LH: This pattern is more characteristic of hypergonadotropic hypogonadism (primary testicular failure) rather than hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

4. Low prolactin: Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is typically associated with normal or high levels of prolactin if there is an underlying pituitary issue. Low prolactin is not a characteristic feature of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, both FSH and LH levels are low, testosterone levels are low, and oligospermia is often present.

 

Ref: Page no 232, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: The maternal part of the placenta is called as? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decidua basalis

 

 

Explanation:

 

The decidua basalis is the specific part of the decidua (the endometrium of the pregnant uterus) that directly interacts with the chorion frondosum (the fetal part of the placenta) to form the maternal part of the placenta.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decidua parietalis: The remaining part of the decidua lining the uterine cavity that is not involved in the formation of the placenta.

 

Option B. Decidua capsularis: The part of the decidua that covers the embryo and the gestational sac, like a capsule.

 

Option D. Decidua spongiosum: This term is not typically used to describe parts of the decidua in the context of placentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Decidua basalis: Forms the maternal part of the placenta.
  • Decidua capsularis: Encloses the rest of the gestational sac.
  • Decidua parietalis: Lines the remainder of the uterus.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient presents with decreased hearing in higher frequencies. It was noted that the basilar membrane was affected. Which of the following structures lie near the affected structure? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oval window

 

The affected structure in high-frequency hearing loss is the basal turn of the cochlea. Among the given options, the structure that lies near it is the oval window.

 

Movements of the stapes footplate, transmitted to the cochlear fluids, move the basilar membrane and set up shearing force between the tectorial membrane and the hair cells. The distortion of hair cells gives rise to cochlear microphonics, which trigger the nerve impulse. A sound wave, depending on its frequency, reaches maximum amplitude on a particular place on the basilar membrane and stimulates that segment (travelling wave theory of von Bekesy). Higher frequencies are represented in the basal turn of the cochlea and the progressively lower ones towards the apex.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Modiolus: The central core of the cochlea around which the cochlear duct spirals. While important, it does not lie near the basal turn directly affected in high-frequency hearing loss.

 

Option B. Stria Vascularis: Located on the outer wall of the cochlear duct and is responsible for producing the endolymph. It plays a crucial role in maintaining the ionic composition of the endolymph but is not located near the oval window.

 

Option D. Helicotrema: The apex of the cochlea where the scala tympani and scala vestibuli meet, it is relevant for the transmission of lower frequency sounds, not high frequencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of high-frequency hearing loss, the basal turn of the cochlea near the oval window is typically involved. Understanding the anatomical proximity of the oval window to the basal turn helps in pinpointing the site of lesion and aids in specific diagnostic and therapeutic approaches aimed at the high-frequency hearing spectrum.

questions.text:
An internist in India is seeing a patient from a minority cultural and linguistic group. To foster therapeutic alliance and provide the best care possible, which of the following approaches should the physician prioritize? [INICET MAY 2022]

 

  1. Insist on good communication.
  2. Insist on communication only via an interpreter.
  3. Treat them regardless of their cultural perceptions.
  4. Consider the patient's religion and cultural perception.
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 1, 4

 

To foster a strong therapeutic alliance and provide high-quality care, the physician should prioritize the following:

 

1. Insist on good communication: Effective communication is crucial for building a strong doctor-patient relationship. Good communication helps in understanding the patient's concerns, explaining medical conditions and treatment options clearly, and ensuring that the patient feels heard and respected.

 

4. Consider the patient's religion and cultural perception: Culturally competent care involves acknowledging and respecting the patient's cultural, religious, and linguistic background. This approach ensures that care is tailored to meet the specific needs and values of the patient, which can enhance their comfort and trust in the healthcare system.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Insist on communication only via an interpreter: Incorrect. While good communication is essential, insisting on communication only via an interpreter may not always be necessary or preferred by the patient.

 

3. Treat them regardless of their cultural perceptions: Incorrect. Treating patients regardless of their cultural perceptions does not align with providing culturally competent care, which aims to respect and incorporate cultural differences into the care plan.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The communication skills of physicians are an effective step of making effective relationship between doctor and patient
  • Research has shown that the way patients perceive their connection with their physician significantly influences their sense of satisfaction and level of concern about their health
  • The goal of culturally competent health care services is to provide the highest quality of care to every patient, regardless of race, ethnicity, cultural background

questions.text: A patient was suspected to have acute brucellosis. A serum sample was sent for a standard agglutination test. It came out to be negative initially but after serial dilutions of the serum sample, the test turned out to be positive. Which of the following is responsible for the initial negative test? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prozone phenomenon

 

The initial negative test is explained by the prozone phenomenon. The standard agglutination test is a tube agglutination test that mainly identifies IgM antibodies. It is used in establishing a diagnosis of acute brucellosis.

 

Prozone phenomenon refers to the failure of a visible precipitation reaction due to inhibition of lattice formation by the presence of excessive antibodies. This gives rise to a false-negative test. This excess in antibodies can be overcome by diluting the serum sample, leading to an increase in LATTICE FORMATION where the antigen-antibody interactions are equal, eventually giving rise to a positive result.

 

Lattice hypothesis: The lattice hypothesis explains precipitation reactions. The amount of precipitate formed is greatly influenced by the relative proportions of antigens and antibodies. The point where the antigen and the antibody are in the same amount , best interaction takes place in this zone called as the zone of equivalence. 

 

  • Prozone phenomenon: Caused by excessive antibodies in the test system. (weak/absent precipitation-false-negative test)
  • Zone of equivalence: Antigens and antibodies are in optimum proportions and maximum precipitation occurs.
  • Post-zone phenomenon: Due to the presence of excessive antigen in the test system. (weaker/absent precipitation)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incomplete antibodies: These are not typically responsible for the phenomenon described. Incomplete antibodies generally do not cause agglutination but can bind antigens.

 

Option B. Complement inactivation: This would not typically result in the observed test pattern and is more relevant in tests involving complement fixation.

 

Option D. Post-zone phenomenon: Occurs when there is an excess of antigen, not antibodies, leading to a lack of visible agglutination due to insufficient cross-linking by antibodies.

 

Educational Objective

 

The prozone phenomenon, responsible for initial false-negative results in serological tests like the standard agglutination test for brucellosis, occurs due to excessive antibodies preventing visible agglutination. This can be corrected by diluting the serum, which highlights the importance of considering antibody concentration in diagnostic testing.

choices.text: Increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine
Increased indirect bilirubin, absent urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine
Increased direct bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine
Increased direct bilirubin, absent urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in physiological jaundice? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

 

In physiological jaundice, there is increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine.

 

Physiological jaundice occurs as a result of increased bilirubin production caused by foetal RB destruction, as well as a transient limitation in bilirubin conjugation in the immature neonatal liver. As a result, indirect/unconjugated bilirubin levels would rise. Increased levels of unconjugated bilirubin in the blood cause an increase in the production of urobilinogen, which is found in large quantities in the urine. Urine bilirubin is uncommon in this condition.

 

Both physiological jaundice (indirect) and hepatocellular jaundice (direct) can have increased urobilinogen - just through different mechanisms:

  • Physiological: ↑ bilirubin load despite immature conjugation
  • Hepatocellular: ↑ conjugated bilirubin reaching gut despite liver damage


 

 

The following indications are suggestive of pathological jaundice and it warrants further investigations for the cause of jaundice.

 

  1. Jaundice appearing in the first 24-36 hours of birth
  2. A rise in serum bilirubin faster than 5mg/dl/24hr
  3. Serum bilirubin > 12mg/dL in a full-term infant(especially if there are no risk factors)
  4. Serum bilirubin > 10-14mg/dL in a preterm infant
  5. Persistent jaundice after 10-14 days of birth
  6. Direct bilirubin > 2mg/dL at any time

 

If there is persistent indirect hyperbilirubinemia for more than 2 weeks it indicates hemolysis, hereditary glucuronyl transferase deficiency, breastmilk jaundice, hypothyroidism, or intestinal obstruction.

 

When the concentration of unconjugated bilirubin exceeds 20-25mg/dL, bilirubin would penetrate the blood-brain barrier and lead to kernicterus.

 

Phototherapy:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Physiological jaundice is characterized by increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, and the absence of bilirubin in the urine.

questions.text: Which can be used as an alternative to breast milk in low birth weight (LBW) child? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Human donor milk

 

  • Human donor milk is the alternative to breast milk in low birth weight infants
  • Low birth weight refers to birth weight less than 2500 grams due to preterm birth or intrauterine growth restriction or both
  • All low birth weight babies should be fed only by breast milk, regardless of the feeding method
  • Expressed breast milk or human donor milk should be given to infants fed by paladai or gastric tube

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Preterm formula & Option C. Term formula: Formula feeds, including term formula feed for infants weighing ≥1500 g at birth and preterm formula feed for very low birth weight infants, can be given when there is a contraindication to breastfeeding or if the mother is sick or human donor milk is not available or toned milk is not available.

 

Option A. Cow milk: Cow milk is not given because it is rich in casein. Casein causes constipation, colicky pain and cow milk protein allergy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Human donor milk is the alternative to breast milk in low birth weight infants

questions.text: A patient presents to the casualty following blunt trauma to the chest. A chest X-ray was done. Among the following radiographs, in which case would you further evaluate the patient before putting a chest tube? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3,4

 

Explanation:

 

  1. Pneumothorax
  2. Hemothorax
  3. Consolidation
  4. Diaphragmatic hernia

 

Image 3: Consolidation would be managed symptomatically and chest tube shouldn’t be inserted.

 

Image 4: Diaphragmatic hernia: A direct blow to the diaphragm can cause it to rupture, allowing abdominal contents to herniate into the chest. In the case of stomach herniation into the chest, a nasogastric tube followed by chest radiography can be helpful. Video-assisted thoracoscopy or laparoscopy is the most accurate investigation.

 

Other Options:

 

Radiographs 1-2 show hemothorax and pneumothorax. Intercostal chest drains should be inserted into the fifth intercostal space. The safe landmark is a triangle anterior to the midaxillary line above the nipple, below, and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of blunt chest trauma, careful evaluation of chest radiographs is crucial. Consolidations (Image 3) and diaphragmatic hernias (Image 4) require specific management strategies distinct from those of pneumothorax or hemothorax, where immediate chest tube placement is standard.

questions.text: Arrange in order the disaster management cycle.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Impact → response → rehabilitation → mitigation

 

Explanation:

 

The correct chronological order of the disaster management cycle is as follows:

 

5 stages -

 

  1. Impact: This is the initial stage when a disaster strikes an area, such as an earthquake, flood, or tsunami.
  2. Response: In this stage, search and rescue operations, first aid, and medical relief efforts are launched.
  3. Rehabilitation: This stage focuses on addressing water, sanitation, food supply, vector control, and other essential services.
  4. Mitigation: Efforts are made to prevent hazards or risks from turning into disasters, minimizing potential damage.
  5. Preparedness: This stage involves planning and preparation for an anticipated disaster, such as a tsunami or earthquake season.

 

The answer to this is choice A, which correctly arranges the stages as impact, response, rehabilitation, and mitigation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct order of the disaster management cycle is impact, response, rehabilitation, mitigation, and preparedness, representing the chronological sequence of actions taken during and after a disaster.

questions.text: Which is the most common Osteoporotic fracture site?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vertebral fracture

 

OSTEOPOROSIS

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • The fractures that are most common (in decreasing order) are vertebral fracture > hip (neck femur) > lower end radius.
  • Most of the vertebral fractures are asymptomatic and are identified incidentally during radiograph for other purpose.
  • Few of these present as backache of varying degree.
  • Up to 70 years of age, the order of fracture incidence is vertebral > Colle’s.
  • Overall and in > 70 years of age, it is vertebral > Hip > Colle’s.
  • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse), codfish appearance and pencilling of vertebrae.

 

X-ray of osteoporotic spine: Codfish vertebra (Biconcave vertebra)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intertrochanteric fracture: These fractures occur both in the elderly and the young, but they are more common in the elderly population with osteoporosis due to a low energy mechanism. These patients are also typically older than patients who suffer femoral neck fractures. In the younger population, these fractures typically result from a high-energy mechanism. The femur is the second most common site of fracture in the osteoporotic patients.

 

Option C. Femoral shaft fracture: Femoral shaft fractures can result from high or low energy mechanisms. The most common causes include automobile accidents, falls from heights, ground-level falls in individuals with osteoporosis, and gunshots. About 75% fractures are caused by high energy mechanisms. Other less common causes are atypical fractures from bisphosphonate use, pathologic fractures through a bone lesion, insufficiency fractures from osteoporosis, and stress fractures from overuse in athletes.

 

Option D. Subtrochanteric fracture: Subtrochanteric fractures are mainly seen in 2 patient populations: spiral fractures in osteoporotic patients and atypical insufficiency fractures that happen after no to low-energy trauma (e.g., patients who use long-term bisphosphate therapy). But femur involvement is the second common site in osteoporosis for fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most common site for osteoporotic fractures is the vertebral column followed by femur (mainly neck) and lower end of the radius.

questions.text: Which of the following is a direct cause of maternal death? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pre-eclampsia

 

Explanation:

 

Maternal deaths can be classified into direct and indirect causes. Direct causes are those that result from complications of pregnancy, labor, or the postpartum period, whereas indirect causes are conditions that are exacerbated by pregnancy.

 

Pre-eclampsia: This is a direct cause of maternal death. Pre-eclampsia is a hypertensive disorder of pregnancy that can lead to severe complications such as eclampsia, HELLP syndrome, stroke, and organ failure, all of which can directly result in maternal mortality.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anemia: This is considered an indirect cause of maternal death. While severe anemia can exacerbate complications during pregnancy and childbirth, it is not a direct cause but increases the risk of infections, hemorrhage, and other complications.

 

Option B. Heart disease: This is also an indirect cause of maternal death. Pre-existing heart disease can worsen during pregnancy due to the increased cardiovascular demands, but it is not a complication arising directly from pregnancy.

 

Option C. Embolism: Pulmonary embolism is considered an indirect cause of maternal death when it occurs due to pregnancy-related factors like deep vein thrombosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pre-eclampsia is a direct cause of maternal death, directly associated with complications arising from pregnancy, labor, or the postpartum period.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the Pediatrics OPD with the complaints of several episodes of melena. On physical examination, there was eczematous rash over the skin with multiple red pin-point hemorrhagic spots. His Hemogram reveals low platelet count and normal RBC and WBC counts. What is the next best investigation? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) WASP gene mutation

 

The clinical symptoms of the patient (recurrent Melena, eczema and red pin-point hemorrhagic spots) are pointing towards the diagnosis of Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome. It occurs due to WASP gene mutation.

 

So Next best step would be to analyze for WASP mutation (Chromosome Xp).

 

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is an X-linked recessive immunodeficiency disorder characterized by –

 

  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Recurrent bleeding (Melena, Epistaxis or Hematemesis)
  • Low Immunity, Recurrent Infections, Eczema
  • Low IgM and high IgA & IgE
  • Normal thymus but reduced T-cells in blood

 

The only treatment for this condition is Bone Marrow Transplantation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anti-platelet antibodies: While these are relevant in conditions like immune thrombocytopenia (ITP), they are not the primary investigation for Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome.

 

Option C. Bone marrow biopsy: This can be used to assess marrow function but is not specific for diagnosing Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome.

 

Option D. Electron microscopy: Although useful in some hematological disorders, it is not the first-line diagnostic tool for Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome should be suspected in a pediatric patient with thrombocytopenia, eczema, and recurrent bleeding episodes, and the next best step is to investigate for a WASP gene mutation.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 439-440

questions.text: Which of the following is represented in the below figure by drug X? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epsilon Amino Caproic acid

 

The diagram illustrates the process of fibrinolysis, where plasminogen is converted into plasmin by activators like streptokinase. Plasmin is responsible for breaking down fibrin into fibrin degradation products, effectively dissolving clots. Drug X, as represented in the diagram, inhibits this process, thereby acting as an anti-fibrinolytic agent. Epsilon Amino Caproic Acid (EACA) is an anti-fibrinolytic drug that works by inhibiting the activation of plasminogen to plasmin, thereby preventing the breakdown of fibrin and stabilizing clots.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clopidogrel: This is an antiplatelet drug that prevents blood clots by inhibiting platelet aggregation. It does not have any direct role in inhibiting fibrinolysis as shown in the diagram.

 

Option C. Tenecteplase: This is a thrombolytic agent that promotes the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin, thereby enhancing fibrinolysis and breaking down clots. It is the opposite of what Drug X does in the diagram.

 

Option D. Aspirin: This is an antiplatelet drug that inhibits the cyclooxygenase enzyme, reducing the formation of thromboxane A2, which is involved in platelet aggregation. Like Clopidogrel, it does not inhibit fibrinolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epsilon Amino Caproic Acid (EACA) is an anti-fibrinolytic drug that inhibits the activation of plasminogen, thereby preventing the breakdown of fibrin and stabilizing blood clots.

questions.text: ASEPSIS wound scoring takes all of the following into consideration except: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Induration

 

ASEPSIS wound score does not take induration into consideration.

 

ASEPSIS wound score and Southampton wound score are used to determine the severity of the surgical site wound infection (SSI).

 

ASEPSIS SCORE

 

 

Criterion Not Included: 

 

Option D. Induration: Induration (hardening of the tissue) is not included in the ASEPSIS wound scoring system. The criteria focus on discharge, erythema, separation of tissues, bacterial isolation, and additional treatments rather than tissue induration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ASEPSIS wound scoring system does not include induration as a criterion. It focuses on factors like purulent and serous discharge, erythema, separation of deep tissue, additional treatments, bacterial isolation, and extended hospital stay to evaluate surgical site infections.

questions.text: Which of the following component is absent in the smooth muscle? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Troponin

 

Smooth muscle, unlike skeletal muscle, does not contain troponin. In smooth muscle cells, actin and myosin are present and are essential for muscle contraction. Tropomyosin is also present in smooth muscle, though its role differs from that in skeletal muscle. While in skeletal muscle, tropomyosin blocks the myosin binding sites on actin filaments, its function in smooth muscle is still not completely understood but is thought to aid in muscle contraction. Troponin, however, is absent in smooth muscle.

 

In skeletal muscle, troponin binds to calcium ions during muscle contraction, facilitating the interaction between actin and myosin.

 

Smooth muscle uses calmodulin to bind calcium instead of troponin, enabling muscle contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Actin: Actin is present in smooth muscle and plays a crucial role in the contraction process by interacting with myosin.

 

Option B. Myosin: Myosin is also present in smooth muscle and is essential for contraction as it interacts with actin.

 

Option C. Tropomyosin: Tropomyosin is present in smooth muscle. Although its exact role differs from that in skeletal muscle, it is involved in the contraction mechanism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Troponin is absent in smooth muscle; instead, calcium binds to calmodulin to facilitate muscle contraction.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man presented with generalized weakness, which increased towards the evening and improved with 5-10 minutes of rest in between. On examination, he also had ptosis and some difficulty in swallowing. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Myasthenia Gravis

 

Myasthenia Gravis (MG) is characterized by fluctuating muscle weakness and fatigability, which typically worsens with activity and improves with rest. The hallmark of MG is weakness that is more pronounced towards the end of the day or after prolonged activity, and this weakness improves after a period of rest.

 

Key features in this patient’s presentation include:

 

  • Generalized weakness that increases in the evening.
  • Improvement in weakness with short rest periods.
  • Presence of ptosis (drooping eyelids) and difficulty in swallowing, which are common manifestations of MG.

 

In MG, autoantibodies attack the acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, impairing neuromuscular transmission. This leads to the characteristic symptoms of fluctuating weakness and fatigability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lambert Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome: Lambert Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS) is a paraneoplastic syndrome often associated with small cell lung cancer. It also involves muscle weakness but typically improves with exercise rather than worsening, which is opposite to the pattern seen in MG.

 

Option C. Peripheral Neuropathy: Peripheral neuropathy generally presents with sensory disturbances, weakness, and diminished reflexes in a stocking-glove distribution. It does not typically cause fluctuating weakness or specific muscle group involvement such as ptosis.

 

Option D. Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy: Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) is a genetic disorder that presents in early childhood with progressive muscle weakness, particularly in the proximal muscles. It is highly unlikely to present in a 76-year-old man as it typically leads to severe disability or death by early adulthood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia Gravis is characterized by fluctuating muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest. Key clinical features include ptosis, difficulty swallowing, and generalized weakness with a diurnal variation.

 

Most sensitive diagnosis is supported by single fiber EMG and most specific investigation is antibody tests, such as acetylcholine receptor antibodies and anti-muscle specific kinase antibodies.

choices.text: Size more than 5.5 cm in males

questions.text: Which of the following are indications for surgical intervention in abdominal aortic aneurysms? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. All of the above

 

To summarize, each of the mentioned criteria - size, symptomatic presentation, and rapid growth - are indications for surgical intervention in abdominal aortic aneurysms. Thus, the answer is: D. All of the above.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Size more than 5.5 cm in males:  An abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) that is greater than 5.5 cm in diameter has an increased risk of rupture. The risk of rupture and complications rises significantly as the size of the aneurysm increases. For this reason, surgical intervention is typically recommended when an AAA reaches this size in males.

 

Option B. Patient is experiencing abdominal pain: Abdominal pain can be a sign that the aneurysm is expanding or is about to rupture. If a patient presents with abdominal pain and an AAA, it's often treated as a surgical emergency. The pain might be caused by the aneurysm pressing on surrounding structures or due to impending rupture.

 

Option C. Expansion of >0.5 cm within 6 months: Rapid expansion of an AAA is another indicator of increased rupture risk. An expansion of more than 0.5 cm in 6 months indicates that the aneurysm is growing quickly. Rapid growth can be a sign of structural changes in the aneurysm wall that increase the risk of rupture. Therefore, even if the AAA is smaller than the usual 5.5 cm threshold, if it's growing quickly, surgical intervention is typically considered.

 

Educational Objective:


Abdominal aortic aneurysms require surgical intervention if the size exceeds 5.5 cm in males, the patient presents with abdominal pain, or if there is an expansion of more than 0.5 cm within 6 months.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy comes with complaints of left ear pain, difficulty in opening the mouth, painful swallowing, and fever. The oral cavity examination reveals the following. The external facial examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is likely? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Quinsy

 

The image shows quinsy also known as a peritonsillar abscess.

 

It is the collection of pus between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx.

 

The clinical features are sore throat/ dysphagia, drooling of saliva, trismus, ipsilateral otalgia, and fever.

 

EXAMINATION FINDINGS

 

  1. The tonsil, pillars and soft palate on the involved side are congested and swollen. Tonsil itself may not appear enlarged as it gets buried in the oedematous pillars
  2. Uvula is swollen and oedematous and pushed to the opposite side.
  3. Bulging of the soft palate and anterior pillar above the tonsil.
  4. Mucopus may be seen covering the tonsillar region.
  5. Cervical lymphadenopathy is commonly seen. This involves jugulodigastric lymph nodes.
  6. Torticollis. Patient keeps the neck tilted to the side of abscess

 

Investigations - Contrast-enhanced CT or MRI shows the abscess and its extent. Needle aspiration of an abscess provides material for culture and sensitivity of bacteria.

 

The management of quinsy is by antibiotics and incision & drainage to drain the abscess followed by interval tonsillectomy 6 weeks later.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pharyngitis: Typically presents with a sore throat and possible fever but lacks the severe localized symptoms and findings of quinsy.

 

Option B. Parotid abscess: Would likely present with swelling and pain in the parotid gland area, externally visible.

 

Option C. Bezold's Abscess: An infection that spreads from the mastoid process into the surrounding tissues, which would involve more distinct signs of ear and mastoid involvement.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Quinsy is a severe infection requiring prompt recognition and treatment to prevent complications. It distinctly affects the peritonsillar area, leading to significant local and systemic symptoms that guide its diagnosis and management.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 299

questions.text: A woman presents with a history of headaches for the past 9 months that worsen in a recumbent position and improve as the day progresses. She also gives a history of taking oral contraceptives. Fundal examination shows papilledema. There are no focal neurological deficits. What is the most probable cause of her headaches? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pseudotumor cerebri

 

Pseudotumor cerebri, also known as idiopathic intracranial hypertension, is characterized by increased intracranial pressure without a detectable cause on imaging. The patient's headaches worsening in a recumbent position, along with papilledema, are classic signs. The history of taking oral contraceptives is a known risk factor for this condition.

 

Diagnostic confirmation typically involves elevated CSF opening pressure (Headache, papilledema) with normal imaging.

 

Treatment –

 

First-Line Treatment: Astazolamide is the treatment of choice. If astazolamide is not suitable or effective, topiramate can be used as an alternative.

 

Management of Refractory Cases: If the condition is refractory to medication (i.e., persistent headache or worsening visual field defects), surgical options may be considered.

 

  • Surgical Options:
  • Lumboperitoneal shunt: This procedure diverts cerebrospinal fluid to reduce intracranial pressure.
  • Optic nerve sheath fenestration: This surgery involves making an opening in the sheath around the optic nerve to relieve pressure, potentially preserving vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myasthenia gravis: This condition typically causes muscle weakness and fatigue, not headaches.

 

Option B. Temporal arteritis: This condition occurs more frequently in older individuals and presents with a unilateral, throbbing headache, often accompanied by other symptoms such as jaw claudication and visual disturbances.

 

Option C. Chronic migraine: While migraines can cause severe headaches, they usually include symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, aura, photophobia, and phonophobia, which are not mentioned in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pseudotumor cerebri should be suspected in patients with chronic headaches that worsen when lying down, especially if they have papilledema and are on oral contraceptives.

questions.text: Structure lies in the floor of inferior horn of lateral ventricle all except (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tail of caudate nucleus

 

The tail of the caudate nucleus is located in the roof of the inferior horn, not the floor.

 

Roof of Inferior horn - Tapetum (part of the corpus callosum), medial part of tail of the Caudate Nucleus and Striate Terminus

 

Floor of Inferior horn – Fimbria, hippocampus, collateral sulcus and collateral eminence.

 

Other Options:

 

The inferior horn of the lateral ventricle is a part of the brain located in the temporal lobe. Structures found in the floor of the inferior horn include the hippocampus, fimbria, and collateral eminence.

 

Option A. Collateral eminence: This is a ridge in the floor of the inferior horn formed by the collateral sulcus.

 

Option B. Hippocampus: A crucial structure for memory conversion, located in the floor of the inferior horn.

 

Option C. Fimbria: A bundle of nerve fibers on the hippocampus that forms part of the floor.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The tail of the caudate nucleus is located in the roof of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle, not in the floor.

questions.text: All the following are functions of the superior oblique muscle except? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adduction

 

The superior oblique muscle is one of the extraocular muscles responsible for controlling eye movements. Its primary functions include:

 

  • Abduction: Moving the eyeball away from the midline of the body. The superior oblique helps in turning the eye outward.
  • Depression: Moving the eyeball downward. The superior oblique assists in looking down, especially when the eye is in an adducted position.
  • Intorsion: Rotating the top of the eye towards the nose. This is the action of rotating the eyeball towards the nose, which is an inward rotation.

 

These functions can be remembered using the mnemonic "SOLID," where:

 

  • Superior Oblique LID stands for Lateral (abduction), Intorsion, and Depression.

 

The superior oblique muscle does not perform adduction, which is moving the eyeball towards the midline of the body. This action is typically performed by the recti muscles, specifically the medial rectus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The superior oblique muscle is responsible for abduction, depression, and intorsion of the eye, but not adduction.

questions.text: Which organ is the earliest to undergo putrefaction from the given options? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Brain

 

Among the given options, the brain is the first organ to undergo putrefaction. The process of putrefaction involves the decomposition of body tissues and follows a specific order from early to late stages.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heart: The heart putrefies after the brain but before the kidneys.

 

Option C. Kidney: The kidneys putrefy after the heart.

 

Option D. Prostate: The prostate putrefies very late in the process, even after the kidneys.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The order of organ putrefaction (early to late) is as follows:

 

  1. Larynx and trachea
  2. Liver and lungs
  3. Brain
  4. Heart
  5. Kidney
  6. Prostate and Non Gravid uterus
  7. Skin, muscle, tendons
  8. Bones and teeth

 

Prostate and Non gravid uterus are organs which putrefy very late. The gravid uterus putrefies earlier.

 

Mnemonic: LBHK

 

L for larynx, liver, lungs, B for brain H for Heart, K for Kidney

questions.text: A 48 year old male smoker presented with cough and foul smelling sputum which increased on change in posture. He had similar episodes multiple times in last few years. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bronchiectasis 

 

Explanation:

 

The key features presented in this case are a 48-year-old male smoker with chronic cough, foul-smelling sputum, and an increase in sputum production upon changing posture. Additionally, the patient has experienced similar episodes multiple times over the past few years. These clinical manifestations strongly suggest a diagnosis of bronchiectasis.

 

Bronchiectasis is a chronic condition characterized by permanent dilation and destruction of the bronchi (airways) due to recurrent inflammation or infection. It leads to impaired clearance of secretions, resulting in the accumulation of thick, foul-smelling sputum within the dilated airways. The sputum production often increases upon postural changes, as described in this case, due to the pooling of secretions within the dilated bronchial segments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Asthma: While asthma can present with cough and wheezing, it is not typically associated with foul-smelling sputum or a significant change in sputum production upon postural changes.

 

Option B. Carcinoma of the lung: Lung cancer can cause cough and sputum production, but the sputum is usually not described as foul-smelling. Additionally, the recurrent nature of the episodes over several years is less consistent with lung cancer.

 

Option D. Lung abscess: A lung abscess can also present with cough and foul-smelling sputum, but it is typically an acute condition and is less likely to have recurrent episodes over several years without appropriate treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with a history of chronic cough, foul-smelling sputum production that increases with postural changes, and recurrent episodes over several years, bronchiectasis should be strongly considered as the likely diagnosis, especially in the presence of risk factors such as smoking.

choices.text: ANOVA is an example of a non-parametric test
It is used for skewed distributions
It involves the assumption that the data has a normal distribution
It cannot be used for small sample sizes

questions.text: Which of the following is true for non-parametric tests? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) It is used for skewed distributions 

 

  • Non-parametric tests are statistical tests that do not require the data to be normally distributed or have a specific population parameter, such as the mean or variance, assumed beforehand. They are typically used when the data are not normally distributed, have outliers, or when the sample size is small.
  • Some examples of non-parametric tests include the Wilcoxon rank-sum test, Kruskal-Wallis test, and Mann-Whitney U test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ANOVA is an example of a non-parametric test:  Is incorrect because ANOVA is a parametric test used to compare the means of two or more groups.

 

Option C. It involves the assumption that the data has a normal distribution: Is incorrect because non-parametric tests do not assume that the data has a normal distribution.

 

Option D. It cannot be used for small sample sizes: Is also incorrect because non-parametric tests can be used for small sample sizes. In fact, they are often preferred over parametric tests for small sample sizes or when the assumptions of parametric tests are violated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-parametric tests are valuable statistical tools when dealing with skewed distributions or when the assumptions of parametric tests (like normal distribution) are not met. They provide robustness against the distribution shape of the data and are effective in handling smaller sample sizes and outliers.

questions.text: Foreign body entry into the laryngeal inlet is prevented by the cough reflex. This reflex is sluggish in alcohol ingestion and some other conditions. Which nerve is likely injured?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Internal laryngeal nerve

 

Cough reflex is a protective mechanism of the larynx to expel foreign irritants in order to keep airway clear. Afferent of this reflex is through internal laryngeal nerve, which gives sensory supply to mucosa above vocal cords. Irritant substances like alcohol affects the nervous system causing inhibition of cough reflex.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glossopharyngeal nerve: Primarily involved in the sensation and taste on the posterior one-third of the tongue, not directly involved in the cough reflex at the larynx.

 

Option C. External laryngeal nerve: Mainly supplies the cricothyroid muscle with motor fibers and does not have a sensory role in the cough reflex.

 

Option D. Recurrent laryngeal nerve: Supplies all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid and provides sensory innervation to the mucosa below the vocal cords; thus, it plays a role in the cough reflex but primarily for the lower part of the larynx.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Damage to or inhibition of the internal laryngeal nerve can significantly impair the cough reflex by reducing the sensory input required to detect irritants above the vocal cords, emphasizing its pivotal role in this protective reflex.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 337
